ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A

The class was mostly a virtual seminar that met Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday. On Wednesdays, we had extra homework instead of class. I think the Prof was supposed to submit another lecture to be viewed asynchronously on Wednesdays, but she never ended up doing this. There were no in-person components to this course, I think the Prof was concerned about being fair to students who were not in New Haven, so although there were in-person components suggested (like in-person language table), but this never happened.
On Wednesdays, we would have pre-recorded practice quizzes.
We mostly had synchronous classes over Zoom, but every Wednesday we had an asynchronous study day to review and do a number of other assignments to solidify our learning.
Use of recorded materials and requirement of recording and writing by students to deepen practice.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I expanded my Korean vocabulary and grammar knowledge. We also spent some time learning about Korean culture (e.g. traditions, folk tales, etc).  Our final project consisted of reviewing six PSAs and creating one. It would have been helpful to spend more time practicing translation from English to Korean, as we often did the opposite and this was not as conducive to learning as one might have hoped.

I learned how to say things like "I heard that John ate ice cream yesterday", "It seems like it is cold outside", "I think that learning Korean is hard", or "Running is very important for health". Also how to say things like "I look like my mother, but my personality is more like my father's". I also learned new vocabulary like "to understand", "stepmother", vocabulary terms related to travel ("to be convenient", "the general price of things", "the people are nice"). We talked about cultural things, like learning about different types of living situations in Korea (boarding houses, apartments, private rentals) and how renting a property in KOrea is different from renting in America. Also learned about how to introduce myself and my family ("My father has a quiet personality, but my brother likes talking to people"). Other cultural things included learning about the Korean folktale about the "daebak"/ big gourd.

130 is a slightly larger jump from 120 compared to 110 vs 120 in that we really start honing in on more complex grammar and learning how to compose longer sentences. The zoom format meant that the course was also majority writing/grammar, as it was a bit difficult to practice speaking
I learned how to communicate in Korean in a more spontaneous manner.
I learned a lot of Korean language as well as culture!
I improved any fluency I had!
Better and broader grasp of Korean vocabulary and grammar.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course did a decent job of covering different grammar patterns and building on existing vocabulary. Much time was also devoted to developing audio comprehension, which was helpful. While the course was early in the morning, Wednesdays were asynchronous lectures, so this allowed for some scheduling flexibility. The workload is also reasonable, and grading isn't too harsh.  Professor Choi was also sometimes flexible with deadlines, which did help. However, the course itself was very disorganized. While some of this was inevitably a result of conducting the class on Zoom, greater clarity all throughout would have been helpful. Often times there was constant confusion as to when assignments were due. The deadlines on the course schedule rarely matched the deadlines set on Canvas. Sometimes assignments would not be published at all, leaving us quite unsure as to whether we should have completed them. The assignments listed on the course schedule sometimes did not correspond to the assignments discussed in class. Grades were not uploaded directly on Canvas, so we had to manually calculate our final grade throughout the course. Test formatting was also different every time, so this also led to a bit of confusion.  The assignments themselves were also not the most engaging and seemed a bit scattered. One of the most enjoyable moments of the class was presenting our final projects, where student either created a PSA or a drama. It would have been nice to see more of this, as well as more engaging class activities overall.

Strengths: lots of exposure to Korean, Prof really cared about the students and was very prompt at responding to questions via email, also made her office hours by appointment very open / flexible. Reasonable difficulty, not too hard and not too easy, felt like a reasonable increase in vocab / knowledge from L2. 

Weaknesses: the class felt disorganized, I often did not know what was due the next day because the assignments on the syllabus didn't match what was actually available on the "Assignments" tab on Canvas. I also never knew what my grade was, because none of the grades were entered into the Grades tab on Canvas. The discussions that I really normally liked in the in-person class were non-existent, because we didn't go into breakout rooms as often as we did in in-person class. And we often had no idea what we were supposed to be talking about in the breakout rooms.

I think that all of the weakness had to do with Zoom. Choi Ssn did a great job of changing the final assignments and the content in order to meet us where we are (she even dedicated several sessions to review once she saw that we were struggling a bit), but Zoom just made it very difficult to both stay engaged with the material and connect with each other as a cohort.
Using breakout rooms to have conversations in Korean was helpful. I sometimes wished that more things were explained in English because sometimes ssn. Chois instructions were a bit hard to follow.
The well researched way she taught us to study was very helpful in retaining the language.
Very good for improving language skills and begin to be able to talk fluently in Korean.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of breakout rooms, in theory, could have served as an opportunity to practice conversational skills. Sometimes this did result in useful practice. However, like is common in most Zoom classes, they tended to devolve into an awkward silence or tangential conversations unrelated to the course. Taking tests on Zoom was also quite challenging. Professor Choi would share her screen and ask us to complete section by section together. However, this proved to be a bit difficult, as Professor Choi would sometimes rush through sections or move from one section of the test. Relying wholly on Canvas also proved to be a bit of an issue.

Succeeded: I really liked the Wednesdays being more homework and no in-person class. I would have felt really burnt out if I had in-person live class every day on Zoom. THe final project also went as well as it could, given the pandemic. Usually it's a group project / vid, but we did our best w/ social distancing.The prof also did a great job grading our submitted assignments on Canvas, it took her a bit to learn how to do it, but it is impressive that she was able to provide such individual feedback for this many students and this many assignments.  

Could be improved: breakout rooms, the assignments on the canvas tab should match the assignments on the syllabus, grades should be posted on the Canvas tab throughout the semester, powerpoints should be posted on canvas before the class
We had a kdrama/PSA learning log assignment which was great for a virtual environment
There might have been too many required TA session. Many student didn't have time. Otherwise it went very well. She was extremely flexible.
Online seminars including break-out rooms were very successful, as well as online assignments such as using recorded materials. However, voice-recording homework was harder due to technical problems.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to a student if they are looking to continue studying Korean. This class is not the most engaging, but it does a decent job of covering important grammar and vocabulary.

This class is really as good as you make it. Some of my friends really learned a lot from this class, I felt like it was OK, but nothing eye-opening. My Korean definitely improved, and I'm glad I can talk more easily with my family members. The class introduced me to new grammar structures that are important to everyday conversation: like "I heard that she said that..." or "It seems like..." I also had to take this course to fulfill my language requirement (I started from L1 as an ethic Korean who knew no Korean), so it was a mandatory thing for me. Just glad I could get this out of the way. I'd only recommend it if you'er looking to fulfill your language requirement or would like to improve your Korean for personal reasons. The class would probably be way bettter in-person than on Zoom.
Yes, but only in person
Yes! The Korean language program at Yale is a very rewarding experience!
Definitely. Professor Choi teaches very well. You'll definitely learn alot.
Yes, the professor makes sure you understand the grammar and improve vocabulary through interactive methods.
